body:
https://builds.apache.org/job/beam_PerformanceTests_JDBC/217/console

Jenkins failed. I'm having one of the issues with jenkins from HadoopInputFormatIOIT PR: https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/4332

I think it is the path to kube config in both cases. @jbonofre could you help with determining what should be the path to kubeconfig file? We don't know the jenkins setup.
There are transient failures in other connectors.  @lukecwik can you please review and commit this change?
Thanks for review @jkff. I've just submitted my fixes and replied to your comments.
Thanks ! Sure, gonna take a look.

Can you try running in Jenkins executor 'beam1' ? It's possible that kubectl is only available in 'beam1'.  See https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/INFRA-14819. (I'm not sure if Apache infra acted on this after my last ping)

Following config shows how to restrict execution to a given set of Jenkins executors.
https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/master/.test-infra/jenkins/job_beam_PostCommit_Python_ValidatesRunner_Dataflow.groovy
Reconsidering this PR, since I just found this doc that says there were significant changes in 0.28.0: https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/docs/python-client-migration
LGTM. Thanks.
Run Java PreCommit
Run Java PreCommit
retest this please
Run Java Postcommit
Closing in favor of #4396, because it turns out multiple changes introduced different dependency edges
Friendly ping.
retest this please
Rebase branch and rerun precommit.

The result of the Flink ValidatesRunner is gone since the last commit was pushed but it was https://builds.apache.org/view/A-D/view/Beam/job/beam_PostCommit_Java_ValidatesRunner_Flink/4665/ so this is as green as it gets for now.

I want to note that we are currently dropping Java 7 support so that this can stay here. But it is worth seeing the `java8` profile below where the `gearpump` runner module lives. Since this will go to a feature branch first and only later to master the switch to Java 8 will certainly be done by then.

> 
>   @Description("The maximum parallelism allowed for a given data source")
> ```

To make sure I understand this - it means that every Samza source will be set to this same max parallelism?

Run Java JdbcIO Performance Test

This pull request allow to run file-based-io tests with Perfkit. It contains definition of pipeline options(pkb-config.yml) that need to be passed to beam in order to run tests. To make it working with PerfKit [#1556](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/PerfKitBenchmarker/pull/1556) **must be merged first.** 
Pom.xml was modified that it contains path to kubernetes scripts and to pkb-config.yml. This allows to dynamically create and configure hdfs infrastructure. Based on `LoadBalancerIp` - ` --hdfsConfiguration` is created and `--filenamePrefix` is modified. 

This PR is working with DirectRunner(check note in pkb-config.yml) and with Dataflow without any additional modifications in config files by running:
`mvn verify -Dio-it-suite-hdfs-small -pl sdks/java/io/file-based-io-tests -DfileBasedIoItClass=org.apache.beam.sdk.io.text.TextIOIT -DpkbLocation="/Path_to_/PerfKitBenchmarker/pkb.py" -DintegrationTestRunner=dataflow -DpkbExtraProperties='["filesystem=hdfs"]' -DintegrationTestPipelineOptions='["--tempRoot=gs://bucket-name/"]' 
`

The jenkins configuration was provided. However additional bq tables must be created first:
- beam_performance.textioit_hdfs_pkb_results
- beam_performance.compressed_textioit_hdfs_pkb_results
- beam_performance.avroioit_hdfs_pkb_results
- beam_performance.tfrecordioit_hdfs_pkb_results

cc @chamikaramj
Gradle build failed due to `MqttIO` test timeout (I have to increase from 5 seconds to 10 seconds as it can happen when the Jenkins executor is loaded). I'm checking for Maven build.
retest this please

Portability does effect this code because the class will not be executing within a runner's classpath any more but within a docker container. You can see a simple diagram here: https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1Tc9MdXTDicb6jVCrXjsCbbnLYQCxYiKlTYdVpRkYdBQ/edit#slide=id.g11bcfc06a9_1_1098

This means that the lifecycle for a container is per job and will not lead to OOME due to class loading.

I still disagree that this is the wrong direction to go and will point out that this change contains no tests and hence will be broken quite easily by any changes.

@robertwb  - I've created a class hierarchy. [Passes Python PostCommit](https://builds.apache.org/job/beam_PostCommit_Python_Verify/3938/), and [PreCommit](https://builds.apache.org/job/beam_PreCommit_Python_MavenInstall/1801/).
Run Flink ValidatesRunner
r:@lostluck r:@herohde

That indeed fixes this issue. However, I'm afraid that this fix is brittle and may leave us open to other problems. Something about the round trip/translation is obviously breaking  `ensureAllReadsConsumed`.
Run Flink ValidatesRunner

Portability will need years to be mainstream cause all java runners will not ude it before a long time since they dont need it and it adds complexity at all layers (deployment, multi language coding etc). Since this is a java bug and I still think we should fix it.

Since default behavior is not affected (single classloader for beam default cases) the risk is more than low but I agree we should add a test to avoid later regressions.

I can try to add one after this PR is merged but sadly not next week. Im happy if you merge this one and affect me a jira to add a test if it works for you.
OK, it looks like `ensureAllReadsConsumed` depends on Java classes rather than URN. Hopefully the real fix is a simple as migrating this method.

There's a known issue with Dataflow right now causing the WordCountIT to fail - it is because of the moster classpath containing all of Flink, Spark, Apex, Gearpump, and Dataflow deps in the same Maven profile. Gradle runs the same tests in a better way so we know they pass. And the gradle build is failing only because of a known broken MqttIO test. I will sickbay all of these today; didn't get to them yesterday.

So, yea, this is green as far as I am concerned.
Ben - can you reorganize the commits into a history of meaningful changes, squashing in any that were just incremental changes during development and review.
@kennknowles What else can I do to get this PR merged?
I've rebased and cleaned this up. Should be ready for merging.

@lukecwik  I have addressed your comments, please take a look. The only thing is validation  on read and write level,  documentation says that it will be called right before running pipeline so providers data should be available at that point, or I am wrong?
LGTM. Should we use futurize for Python 2 as well and remove the branch?
Not strictly part of this change, but included a fix for `getAdditionalInputs` of the primitive single-output override.
It is good to go. I was just waiting for test results, if I recall.
LGTM
All the failures in the tests are known broken on `master`.
LGTM

Note that a pipeline template in Dataflow is created by running the pipeline with the TemplatingDataflowRunner which saves the job description in Dataflow. The validation happens while still executing on the users machine before the template is created.

ValueProviders are only useful during pipeline execution.
This should fix the underlying problem. If there are no more comments, I believe this is ready to commit.
Is this sufficient? Or should we be generating (and somehow selectively choosing) proto files generated targeting Py3?
R: @jkff

Fair enough. I shouldn't use the fact that our current output is a spam of debug-only info as an excuse to add more. To have a decent CLI to expose this, we should support `--verbose` or `--debug` etc, so a user (or contributor) doesn't have to tweak a logging backend, which almost universally have terrible interfaces for one-off adjustments. Filed https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-3475. --- *[sdks/java/harness/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/fn/harness/control/ProcessBundleHandler.java, line 189 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4356#-L2MfRg7d6PTNTGKz0FY:-L2gIgAz41sESHK5sw6g:btao1bh) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/5a38bdee4d640967ccbcfaa82516e448d3b1ef66/sdks/java/harness/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/fn/harness/control/ProcessBundleHandler.java#L189)):*

That seems problematic in and of itself. This logic should all happen during registration, since it is basic one-time validation of the process bundle descriptor. But it can be fixed later if/when it shows up in performance info, I guess. --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4356)*

@lukecwik  In this case if we have tableId provided via dynamic value provider there is no way to validate if table is there. I can modify validate to only check it for static value provider. Do you think this is a way to go? Or may be there is a better way to handle it.

It does still include a commit and a revert of that commit. Seems silly to add both.
I left that so it's easy enough to cherry pick the change back in when we switch to Java 8. I'll just remove it altogether.
I've removed the commit/revert pair.
Closing without merge
@guruimage not sure what you mean? SpannerIO is already available, though there are more improvements continuously being made.
You don't need to use the same clock since nothing is looking at how far the clock advanced but updated regardless.

I was wondering if we could just encode the sketch itself and not 'depth' and 'width' parameters as they can be retrieved from the sketch. (see Sketch Coder) 
It would optimize memory at the cost of little more computations for each decoding.
What do you think?

@charlesccychen hi Charles. I've removed the context tracking part, and added only the bytes tracking. Appending the bytes tracker is behind an experiment flag, so the performance impact should be none with flag deactivated. I'll work further on a different PR to do the context tracking.

Can you add some detail about the particular changes in the commit log? I had to deduce what it was you were actually fixing, and there seem to be a few unrelated improvements (which you could just leave in). Can you clarify which of these are the fix?

I see these three seemingly independent changes:

1. Using a concurrent `Set` implementation in `testWrite()`. But that test wasn't a problem AFAIK. The map isn't used concurrently, and the `join()` provides adequate memory barrier, I think... but certainly seems better style to use a concurrent structure across threads. (incidentally it is the deprecated style of thread launching)
2. Joining the publisher thread before disconnecting. This seems like a very real fix.
3. Using `QoS.EXACTLY_ONCE`. I didn't see errors that looked like duplication, but I agree that from the code it looks possible.

To be clear: all three seem like OK improvements but I'd love to know which are required and which are nice to have, etc.
